revisions.rev:
{{Infobox software |name = Microsoft Office 2010 |logo = [[File:Microsoft Office 2010 Logo.svg|200px|Microsoft Office 2010 logo]] |screenshot = [[File:Office 2010 family.png|300px|]] |caption = Microsoft Office 2010 applications shown on [[Windows 7]] (clockwise from top left: Word, Excel, OneNote, PowerPoint; these four programs make up the Home and Student Edition) |developer = [[Microsoft]] |released = {{Start date|2010|6|15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/Presspass/press/2010/jun10/06-152010OfficeLaunchPR.mspx|title=Microsoft Office 2010 Now Available for Consumers Worldwide}} |latest release version = Service Pack 1 (14.0.6023.1000) |latest release date = {{Start date and age|2011|06|28}} |operating system = [[Windows 7]]
[[Windows Server 2008]]
[[Windows Vista]] with Service Pack 1
[[Windows Server 2003 R2]]
[[Windows XP]] with Service Pack 3 (32-Bit only) |platform = [[IA-32|Intel x86 32-bit]] and [[x86-64|64-bit]] |language = English, Arabic, Simplified Chinese, Traditional Chinese, Czech, Danish, Dutch, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Hebrew, Hindi, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Lithuanian, Norwegian (BokmÃ¥l), Polish, Portuguese (Brazil), Portuguese (Portugal), Romanian, Russian, Slovak, Slovenian, Spanish, Swedish, Thai, Turkish, and Ukrainian.{{cite web|url=http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc179219.aspx|title=Language identifiers and OptionState Id values in Office 2010|publisher=Microsoft|date=2010-05-12|accessdate=2010-08-16}} |genre = [[Office suite]] |license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] [[Commercial software|commercial]] |website = {{URL|microsoft.com/office/2010}} }} '''Microsoft Office 2010''' (also called '''Office 2010''' and '''Office 14'''{{cite web |title=Office Version Releases And Its Codenaming |url=http://microsoftoffice2010.us/microsoft-office-versions }}) is a [[Office Suite|productivity suite]] for [[Microsoft Windows]],{{cite web |title=Next Office and Exchange named 2010 |url=http://bink.nu/news/next-office-and-exchange-named-2010.aspx |first=Steven |last=Bink |date=2009-04-10 |accessdate=2009-04-10}} and the successor to [[Microsoft Office 2007]]. Office 2010 includes extended file format support, [[user interface]] updates, and a changed user experience.{{cite web |url=http://officebeta.microsoft.com/en-us/msproducts/starter/office-starter-upgrade-to-microsoft-office-2010-FX101792280.aspx |title=What is Office Starter 2010? - Starter - Microsoft Office |publisher=Officebeta.microsoft.com |date= accessdate=2010-06-15 }} A [[64-bit]] version of Office 2010{{cite web |title=Confirmed: Office 2010 comes in 32-bit, 64-bit flavors |url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/04/confirmed-office-2010-will-come-in-32-bit-and-64-bit.ars |first=Emil |last=Protalinski |date=2009-04-14 }} is available, although not for [[Windows XP]] or [[Windows Server 2003]].{{cite web |url=http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee681792%28office.14%29.aspx |title=64-bit editions of Office 2010 |publisher=Technet.microsoft.com |date=2010-05-12 |accessdate=2010-06-15 }}{{cite web |url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/12/microsoft-why-office-2010-wont-support-windows-xp-64-bit.ars |title=Why Office 2010 won't support Windows XP 64-bit }} On April 15, 2010, Office 2010 was released to manufacturing. The suite became available for retail and online purchase on June 15, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://microsoftoffice2010.us/download-office-2010|title=Announcement: Office 2010 Available for Consumers Worldwide}} Office 2010 is the first version to require [[product activation]] for volume license editions.[http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee624358.aspx Plan volume activation of Office 2010] Office 2010 marks the debut of free online versions of Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and OneNote, which work in the web browsers [[Internet Explorer]], [[Firefox]], [[Google Chrome|Chrome]] and [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]], but not [[Opera (web browser)|Opera]]. Office Starter 2010, a new edition of Office, replaced the low-end home productivity software, [[Microsoft Works]]. Microsoft's update to its mobile productivity suite, [[Microsoft Office Mobile|Office Mobile 2010]], will also be released for Windows Phones running [[Windows Mobile|Windows Mobile 6.5]] and [[Windows Phone 7]]. In Office 2010, every application features the [[ribbon (computing)|ribbon]], including [[Microsoft Outlook|Outlook]], [[Microsoft OneNote|OneNote]], [[Microsoft Publisher|Publisher]], [[Microsoft InfoPath|InfoPath]], [[Microsoft SharePoint Workspace|SharePoint Workspace]] (previously known as Groove), and the new [[Office Web Apps]]. As of July 2011, more than 100 million licenses to Office 2010 have been sold.[http://www.zdnet.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-400-million-windows-7-and-100-million-office-2010-licenses-sold-and-more-partner-conference-stats/9988] ==History and development== Development started in 2007 while [[Microsoft]] was finishing work on Office 12, released as [[Microsoft Office 2007]]. The version number 13 was skipped because of the [[triskaidekaphobia|fear of the number 13]].{{cite web | title=Office 2010 FAQ | url=http://www.winsupersite.com/office/office2010_faq.asp | work=Paul Thurrott | publisher=Penton Media, Inc. | date=May 14, 2009 | accessdate=2009-05-25}} It was previously thought that Office 2010 (then called Office 14) would ship in the first half of 2009.{{cite web | title=Office 14: Think first half of 2009 | url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/microsoft/?p=259 | work=Mary Jo Foley | publisher=CBS Interactive Inc. | date=February 14, 2007 | accessdate=2009-05-25}} On January 10, 2009, screenshots of an Office 2010 [[Alpha test|alpha]] build were leaked by a tester. On April 15, 2009, Microsoft confirmed that Office 2010 would be released in the first half of 2010. They announced on May 12, 2009, at a Tech Ed event, a trial version of the 64-bit edition.{{cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-10236813-56.html| title=Office 2010 preview program coming in July|first=Ina| last=Fried| date=May 11, 2009| accessdate=2010-06-04| publisher=CNET}}{{cite web|title=Confirmed: Office 2010 will come in 32-bit, 64-bit flavors|url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/04/confirmed-office-2010-will-come-in-32-bit-and-64-bit.ars| first=Emil| last=Protalinski| publisher=Ars Technica| date=April 14, 2009| accessdate=2010-06-04}} The Technical Preview 1 (Version: 14.0.4006.1010) was leaked on May 15, 2009.{{cite news | url=http://www.neowin.net/news/software/09/05/11/sign-up-for-the-office-2010-technical-preview-due-in-july | title=Sign up for the Office 2010 Technical Preview, due in July | last=Symons | first=Sam | work=Neowin.net | date=May 11, 2009 | accessdate=October 30, 2010}} An internal post-beta build was leaked on July 12, 2009. This was newer than the official preview build and included a "Limestone" internal test application.{{cite news |title=Office 2010 Build 14.0.4302.1000 Leaked |date=2009-07-14 |accessdate=2009-07-14 |url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Office-2010-Build-14-0-4302-1000-Leaked-116694.shtml | notes=The EULA indicates Beta 2}} On July 13 Microsoft announced Office 2010 at its Worldwide Partner Conference 2009. On July 14, 2009, Microsoft started to send out invitations on [[Microsoft Connect]] to test an official preview build of Office 2010.{{cite news |title=Microsoft kicks off Office 2010 Technical Preview |date=2009-07-14 |accessdate=2009-07-14 |url=http://www.neowin.net/news/main/09/07/14/microsoft-kicks-off-office-2010-technical-preview}} On August 30, 2009, the beta build 4417 was leaked on the internet via [[BitTorrent (protocol)|torrents]].{{cite web|title=Microsoft Office 2010 Build 4417 Leaks|url=http://thetechnopath.com/microsoft-office-2010-build-4417-beta-1-leaked-screenshots/|date=2009-08-30|accessdate=2009-08-30|publisher=The Technopath}} The public beta has been available to subscribers of [[Microsoft TechNet|TechNet]], [[Microsoft Developer Network|MSDN]] and Microsoft Connect users as of November 16, 2009.[http://geeksmack.net/microsoft/810-microsoft-office-2010-public-beta-bits-available-on-msdntechnet.html ]{{Dead link|date=June 2010}} On November 18, 2009, the beta was officially released to the general public at the [http://www.microsoft.com/office2010 Microsoft Office Beta website], which was originally launched by Microsoft on November 11, 2009 to provide screenshots of the new office suite.{{cite news|url= http://technologizer.com/2009/11/18/microsoft-opens-up-the-office-2010-beta/ | title=Microsoft Opens Up the Office 2010 Beta | date=November 18, 2009 | first=Harry | last=McCracken | work=Technologizer | accessdate=October 30, 2010}} Office 2010 Beta was a free, fully functional version and expired on October 31, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/office/2010/en/faqs/default.aspx#16q |title=Office Products - Microsoft Office |publisher=Microsoft.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-15}} In an effort to help customers and partners with deployment of Office 2010, Microsoft launched an Office 2010 application compatibility program with tools and guidance available for download.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.technet.com/gray_knowlton/archive/2009/10/22/announcing-the-office-2010-application-compatibility-program.aspx |title=Announcing the Office 2010 Application Compatibility Program - Gray Matter - Site Home - TechNet Blogs |publisher=Blogs.technet.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-15}} On February 5, 2010, the official release candidate build 4734.1000 was available to Connect and MSDN testers. It was leaked to torrent sites.{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Office-2010-RC-Build-4734-1000-Released-134098.shtml|title=Office 2010 RC Build 4734.1000 Released - To testers - Softpedia|publisher=News.softpedia.com|date=2010-02-04|accessdate=2010-06-15}} A few days after, the [[Software_release_life_cycle#RTM|RTM]] Escrow build was leaked. Microsoft announced the RTM on April 15, 2010 and that the final version was to have speech technologies for use with [[text to speech]] in [[Microsoft OneNote]], [[Microsoft PowerPoint]], [[Microsoft Outlook]], and [[Microsoft Word]]. Office 2010 was to be originally released to business customers on May 12, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.technet.com/office2010/archive/2010/04/15/office-2010-reaches-rtm.aspx|title=Office 2010 Reaches RTM! - Microsoft Office 2010 Engineering - Site Home - TechNet Blogs|publisher=Blogs.technet.com|date=2010-04-16|accessdate=2010-06-15}} Business customers with [[Microsoft Software Assurance|Software Assurance]] were able to get it since April 27, 2010 and other Volume Licensing Customers were able to get it since May 1.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/194444/office_2010_clears_last_hurdle_to_release.html?tk=nl_dnx_h_crawl|title=Office 2010 Clears Last Hurdle to Release - PCWorld Business Center |publisher=Pcworld.com|date=2010-04-16|accessdate=2010-06-15}} MSDN and TechNet subscribers have been able to download the RTM version since April 22, 2010. The RTM version number was 14.0.4760.1000. On June 15, 2010, Office 2010 was released to retail customers. On November 17, 2010, Microsoft sent out invitations to a select number of testers at the Microsoft Connect portal to test a beta build of Office 2010 Service Pack 1 (SP1).{{cite web|url=http://thenextweb.com/microsoft/2010/11/17/microsoft-office-2010-sp1-beta-is-out-for-early-testing/|title=Microsoft Office 2010 SP1 beta is out for early testing|publisher=thenextweb.com|date=2010-11-17|accessdate=2011-04-09}} The final version was released to the public on June 28, 2011 with a version number of 14.0.6023.1000. ==New features and improvements== {{Stack| [[File:Word 2010.png|right|200px|thumb|Word 2010]] [[File:Excel 2010.png|right|200px|thumb|Excel 2010]] [[File:PowerPoint 2010.png|right|200px|thumb|PowerPoint 2010]] [[File:OneNote 2010.png|right|200px|thumb|OneNote 2010]] [[File:Office 2010 Backstage.png|200px|thumb|Backstage is a new feature to Office 2010, providing document overview and options]] }} Office 2010 is more "role-based" than previous versions.Krill, Paul. "Microsoft eyes 'people-ready' software."InfoWorld, 5 April 2006. Accessed at http://www.infoworld.com/article/06/04/05/77167_HNwittssoftware2006_1.html on February 14, 2007. There are features tailored to employees in "roles such as research and development professionals, sales people, and human resources." In its [[Internet]] implementation, Office 2010 incorporates features of [[SharePoint Server]] and borrows from "[[Web 2.0]]" ideas.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/microsoft/?p=194 |title=Microsoftâs Office 2007 team wants in on Web 2.0 |author=Mary Jo Foley |date=January 10, 2007 |work=All about Microsoft |publisher= |accessdate=26 September 2010}} Microsoft Office 2010 includes updated support for ISO/IEC 29500:2008, the International Standard version of [[Office Open XML]] (OOXML) file format.[http://www.microsoft.com/Presspass/press/2008/may08/05-21ExpandedFormatsPR.mspx Microsoft Expands List of Formats Supported in Microsoft Office] Office 2010 provides read support for ECMA-376, read/write support for ISO/IEC 29500 Transitional, and read support for ISO/IEC 29500 Strict.[http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc179190.aspx Overview of the XML file formats in Office 2010] In its pre-release (beta) form, however, Office 2010 only supported the Transitional variant, and not the Strict.[http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2010/04/iso-ooxml-convener-microsofts-format-heading-for-failure.ars ISO OOXML convener: Microsoft's format "heading for failure"][http://www.adjb.net/post/Microsoft-Fails-the-Standards-Test.aspx Microsoft Fails the Standards Test] The intent of the ISO/IEC is to allow the removal of the Transitional variant from the ISO/IEC compliant version of the OOXML standard. Microsoft Office 2010 supports [[OpenDocument|OpenDocument Format (ODF)]] 1.1, which is an [[OASIS (organization)|OASIS]] standard. New features also include a built-in screen capture tool, a background removal tool, a protected document mode, new SmartArt templates and author permissions. The 2007 "Office Button" was replaced with a menu button that leads to a full-window file menu, known as Backstage View, giving easy access to task-centered functions such as printing and sharing. A notable [[assistive technology|accessibility]] regression from 2007 is that the menu button scores worse with the [[Fitts's law]] accessibility calculation than previous versions. A modified [[ribbon (computing)|Ribbon]] interface is present in all Office applications, including Office [[Microsoft Outlook|Outlook]], [[Microsoft Visio|Visio]], [[Microsoft OneNote|OneNote]], [[Microsoft Project|Project]], and [[Microsoft Publisher|Publisher]]. Office applications also have functional [[jumplist]]s in [[Windows 7]], which would allow easy access to recent items and tasks relevant to the application.[http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2008/feb08/02-05visio.mspx Microsoft Visio Conference Previews Upcoming New Features for Visio Users][http://www.beingmanan.com/wp/2009/05/office-2010-new-features/ Office 2010: New Features][http://www.microsoft.com/Presspass/exec/steve/2007/10-30OPConferenceBallmer.mspx Microsoft Office Project Conference 2007] Features of Office 2010 include: * Ribbon interface and Backstage View across all applications * Background Removal Tool * Letter Styling * The Word 2007 Equation editor is common to all applications, replacing Microsoft Equation Editor 3.0 * New SmartArt templates * New text and image editing effects * Screen Capturing and Clipping tools * Live collaboration functions * [[Jumplist]]s in Windows 7 * New animations and transitions in PowerPoint 2010 * View Side by Side/Synchronous Scrolling in Word 2010 A new feature in Microsoft Office 2010 is Outlook Social Connector, which allows users to connect to and receive updates from their [[social network]] inside Microsoft Outlook. When users view their emails a name, picture, and title is available for the person they are contacting. Upcoming appointments can also be viewed with this new feature and users can request friends. Outlook Social Connector currently supports [[Facebook]], [[LinkedIn]], [[MySpace]] and [[Windows Live Messenger]].{{cite web |url = http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/outlook/social-connector-for-microsoft-outlook-HA101794273.aspx |title = The power of social networking within Outlook |work = Microsoft Office Website |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |accessdate = 10 October 2010 }} The Volume edition can be activated using a Multiple Activation Key (MAK) which is limited by the number of times a machine can activate when connected to Microsoft's servers, or using a Key Management Server (KMS) which requires activation every 180 days. ==Removed features== The following features are removed from Microsoft Office 2010. ;Removed from the entire suite: * [[Microsoft Office Document Imaging]] application * [[Microsoft Office Document Scanning]] application * Office Startup Assistant (Osa.exe) * Office Diagnostics tool * Support for [[MSXML]] version 5[http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc178954(office.14).aspx#BKMK_WhatsRemoved Changes in Office 2010: What's removed] * Research and Reference pane for Internet Explorer[http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc179199(office.14).aspx#BKMK_Remmoved Changes in Word 2010: What's removed] ;Features removed from Microsoft Word: * [[Smart tag (Microsoft)|Smart Tag]] auto-recognition[http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms178786.aspx Smart Tags Overview] * ''Person Name'' smart tag * AutoSummary feature * Support for Word Add-in Libraries (WLL) ;Features removed from Microsoft Access: * Access Calendar ActiveX control * Replication Conflict Viewer * Data access pages[http://technet.microsoft.com/en-ca/library/cc179181.aspx#BKMK_WhatsRemoved Changes in Access 2010] ;Features removed from Microsoft Outlook * ANSI offline Outlook data files (.ost) for Exchange synchronization * Calendar rebasing tool * [[WebDAV|DAV]] connectivity for HTTP account types * Exchange 2000 connectivity * Exchange Message Security feature support * Postmarks[http://technet.microsoft.com/en-ca/library/cc179110.aspx#BKMK_WhatsRemoved Outlook 2010 Changes] ;Features removed from Microsoft PowerPoint * Macro recorder * Save as Web Page feature[http://technet.microsoft.com/en-ca/library/cc179126.aspx#BKMK_Remmoved Changes in PowerPoint 2010] ;Features removed from Microsoft Publisher * The ability to create new Web Publications{{cite web|url=http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee694636.aspx |title=Changes in Publisher 2010 |publisher=Technet.microsoft.com |date=2010-05-12 |accessdate=2010-06-15}} ==Editions== ===Trial Version=== The Office 2010 Trialhttp://office.microsoft.com/en-us/try/ has an option to download the local install, however the default trial installs an App-V image like Office Starter 2010. The Applicatons Virtualization installer will create a Launcher and Office 2010 will run from a virtual drive letter "Q:" rather than installed in "drive:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office14". This drive letter is not visible in Windows Explorer. Many programs that rely on Windows apppath variable or program location (like Outlook autodiscover using CNAME record) will fail. ===Starter Edition=== Office Starter 2010 is an ad-supported product which includes ''Microsoft Word Starter 2010'' and ''Microsoft Excel Starter 2010''. These are reduced-functionality versions for viewing, editing, and creating documents. Office Starter 2010 is only available to [[original equipment manufacturer]]s (OEM) for preloading on Windows PCs and is intended to replace [[Microsoft Works]]. It is only compatible with Windows Vista and Windows 7.http://pctechwise.com/featured/whats-new-in-microsoft-office-2010 The advertisements are displayed in the lower right area of the task pane. It also includes ''PowerPoint Viewer 2010'', to view and print PowerPoint slides and shows. Users who have Office Starter preinstalled are allowed to load it on a USB drive and run it temporarily on any computer to which the USB drive is connected.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/microsoft/?p=4643 |title=Office Starter 2010: The fine print on Microsoft's Works replacement |date=23 November 2009 |accessdate=15 December 2009 |publisher=[[ZDNet]] |last=Foley |first=Mary Jo }}{{cite web |url=http://blogs.technet.com/office2010/archive/2009/10/07/new-ways-to-try-and-buy-microsoft-office-2010.aspx |title=New Ways to Try and Buy Microsoft Office 2010 |work=Microsoft Office 2010 Engineering blog |publisher=Microsoft Corporation |date=7 October 2009 |accessdate=15 December 2009 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.blogsdna.com/5795/how-to-create-portable-office-2010-starter-usb-flash-drive.htm |title=How to Create Portable Office 2010 Starter USB Flash Drive |publisher=Blogsdna |date=24 November 2009 |accessdate=31 March 2011 }} Office Starter 2010 is available to OEMs for pre-loading on new computers as part of the Office 2010 OEM Pre-installation Kit (OPK). It installs as a virtual application using [[Microsoft App-V]] application virtualization technology[http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2257628 Office 2010 Starter Virtual (Q:) drive may intermittently disappear from My Computer] and can therefore co-exist with full editions of Office. Office Starter 2010 omits several features available only in the full paid version of Microsoft Office. Specifically, it lacks the following features [http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/starter-help/word-features-that-are-not-fully-supported-in-word-starter-HA010374498.aspx Word features that are not fully supported in Word Starter][http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/starter-help/excel-features-that-are-not-fully-supported-in-excel-starter-HA010374501.aspx Excel features that are not fully supported in Excel Starter]: * Customizable quick access toolbar buttons in both programs * SmartArt * Math and equation editing * Full screen reading view in both programs, custom views in Excel Starter * Reference features (Citation, Bibliography etc.) * Tracked changes and comments * Compare and combining documents * Document permissions and protection * Automatic table of contents and table of figures or authorities * Macros * Add-ins * Any additional custom commands not exposed in the ribbon * Bookmarks * Cross references * Footnotes and endnotes * Captions and index * Signature line and digital signatures * AutoText * Content controls and objects * Building Blocks Organizer * Language packs to change the user interface * Built-in sharing via fax recipient or saving to [[SharePoint]] * PivotTables and PivotCharts in Excel Starter * Slicers in Excel Starter * Connections to external data, data validation rules, consolidated data and data tables in Excel Starter * Error checking, calculation steps and circular references in Excel Starter * Modifications to column and row headings in Excel Starter * Ability to toggle row groupings, panes and workbook windows in Excel Starter ===Comparison=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; margin:auto;" |+Table of Editions{{Cite web |url = http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/buy/office-2010-which-suite-is-right-for-you-FX101825640.aspx |title = Which suite is right for you? |work = [[Microsoft Office website]] |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |accessdate = 5 February 2011 }}{{Cite web |url = http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/buy/office-2010-volume-licensing-suites-comparison-FX101825637.aspx |title = Compare suites available through Volume Licensing |work = Microsoft Office website |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |accessdate = 5 February 2011 }}{{Cite web |url = http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/professional-academic/ Corporation |accessdate = 13 May 2011 }} |- ! style="text-align:center; width:15%;"| Suites{{Cite web |url = http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/suites/ |title = Microsoft Office suites |work = || {{No}} || {{Partial|Volume edition only}} || {{No}} || {{Partial|Volume edition only}} |} {{Refbegin}} ;Remarks: :1 Office Home and Student boxed product can be installed on three PCs in the same household and is for non-commercial use. :2 Retail version is offered through [[Microsoft Developer Network|MSDN]] or [[Microsoft TechNet|TechNet]] only.{{Cite web |url = http://blogs.zdnet.com/Bott/?p=2025 |title = Microsoft releases Office 2010, SharePoint 2010 to TechNet, MSDN |work = ZDNet |publisher = CBS Interactive |date = 22 April 2010 |accessdate = 5 February 2011 |quote = Currently, two downloads are available at each site: 32-bit (x86) and 64-bit (x64) versions of the Professional Plus Retail e(.MSP) file and replaces the Custom Installation Wizard and Custom Deployment Wizard included in 2003 and earlier versions of the Office Resource Kit which created a Windows Installer Transform (.MST). }} :3 Office Customization Tool is used to customize the installation of Office by creating a [[Windows Installer#Miscellaneous|Windows Installer Patch]] (.MSP) file and replaces the Custom Installation Wizard and Custom Deployment Wizard included in 2003 and earlier versions of the Office Resource Kit which created a Windows Installer Transform (.MST). Office Customization Tool is only included in Volume License editions. :4 Boxed SKUs of ''Home and Business'' or ''Professional'' editions of the product can be installed on two devices: A primary PC and a portable device such as a laptop.{{cite web|title=Office 2010 Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/products/office-2010-frequently-asked-questions-HA101674631.aspx|work=[[Microsoft Office website]]|publisher=Microsoft Corporation|accessdate=20 September 2011|quote=If you purchase a Traditional Disc retail license of Office Home and Business 2010 or Office Professional 2010, the retail license terms allow you to install, activate, and use Office Home and Business 2010 or Office Professional 2010 on your primary PC and your portable device such as your laptop. This license is for your use exclusively.}} {{Refend}} ===Office Web Apps=== {{Main|Office Web Apps}} Microsoft now offers a free web-based version of its Office productivity suite, known as Office Web Apps, that started shortly before Office 2010 was released to retail stores.[http://www.informationweek.com/news/software/hosted/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=211800059 Microsoft Office 14 To Include Web Apps] Office Web Apps include online versions of [[Microsoft Word|Word]], [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]], [[Microsoft PowerPoint|PowerPoint]] and [[Microsoft OneNote|OneNote]]. The web apps allow sharing and collaboration of documents and files and also feature user interfaces similar to their desktop counterparts. Office Web Apps were released to [[Windows Live Skydrive]] and SharePoint Workspace on June 2010. You may use the free web-based version of Office to create documents, and can download Office Viewers to view the documents on your system. ===Office Mobile 2010=== {{Main|Microsoft Office Mobile}} The office suite for [[Windows Mobile]] by Microsoft, is updated together with Office 2010. Windows Mobile 6.5 or higher is required to run Microsoft Office Mobile 2010.
Some of the new features included are:{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/office/2010/en/mobile/default.aspx|title=Top 10 benefits of Office Mobile 2010|publisher=Microsoft.com}} * '''Presentation Companion:''' The add-on to PowerPoint Mobile allows users to control a presentation through their Windows Phone and display speaker notes. * '''Conversation View:''' Outlook Mobile threads related emails into a group for easier reading and management * '''SharePoint Workspace Mobile:''' The new application allows users to sync documents from SharePoint servers directly to their Windows Phone for offline viewing and editing. * '''Support for New Content in Office 2010''' such as SmartArt graphics and charts An upgrade for the existing Windows Mobile 6.5 Phones is provided via Windows Mobile Marketplace, a beta version is already available.
'''Minimum System Requirements''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! Suites !! Processor !! Memory !! Hard Disk Space !! Display |- | Office Home and Student 2010 || 500 MHz or faster || 256 MB RAM; 512 MB recommended || 3.0 GB || 1024x576 or higher resolution monitor |- | Office Home and Business 2010 || 500 MHz or faster || 256 MB RAM; 512 MB recommended || 3.0 GB || 1024x576 or higher resolution monitor |- | Office Standard 2010 || 500 MHz or faster || 256 MB RAM; 512 MB recommended || 3.0 GB || 1024x576 or higher resolution monitor |- | Office Professional 2010 || 500 MHz or faster || 256 MB RAM; 512 MB recommended || 3.0 GB || 1024x576 or higher resolution monitor |- | Office Professional Plus 2010 || 500 MHz or faster || 256 MB RAM; 512 MB recommended || 3.5 GB || 1024x'''768''' or higher resolution monitor |- | Office Professional Academic 2010 || 500 MHz or faster || 256 MB RAM; 512 MB recommended || 3.0 GB || 1024x576 or higher resolution monitor |} ''Operating System''-Windows XP (must have SP3) (32-bit), Windows 7, Windows Vista with Service Pack (SP) 1, Windows Server 2003 with SP2 and MSXML 6.0 (32-bit Office only), Windows Server 2008, or later 32- or 64-bit OS.
Graphics hardware acceleration requires a DirectXÂ® 9.0c graphics card with 64 MB or more video memory. ==See also== * [[Microsoft Office for Mac 2011]], the release of Microsoft Office for [[Mac OS X]] containing many of Office 2010's new features * [[List of office suites]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{Cite web |url = http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/professional-plus/ |title = Office Professional Plus 2010 |work = [[Microsoft Office website]] |publisher = Microsoft corporation |accessdate = 5 February 2011 }} {{Cite web |url = http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/lync/ |title = Microsoft Lync 2010 |work = Microsoft Office website |publisher = Microsoft corporation |accessdate = 5 February 2011 }} {{Cite web |url = http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc179097(office.14).aspx |title = Office Customization Tool in Office 2010: Office 2010 Technical Reference |work = [[Microsoft TechNet]] |publisher = Microsoft Corporation |date = 16 December 2010 |accessdate = 5 February 2011 |quote = The OCT is available only with volume licensed versions of Office 2010 and the 2007 Office system. To determine whether an Office 2010 installation is a volume licensed version, check the Office 2010 installation disk to see whether it contains a folder named Admin.
